newsitem.title: USA: Venezuelan Petrozuata partners tap loan arrangers.
newsitem.headline: Venezuelan Petrozuata partners tap loan arrangers.

text.p: E.I. Dupont de Nemours & Co energy unit Conoco and state-owned Petroleos de Venezuela subsidiary Maraven on Thursday named four international banks to arrange $700 million in senior debt financing for their $2.2 billion Petrozuata oil project, sources said on Thursday.
The partners tapped Credit Suisse, ING Barings, Nationsbank and Union Bank of Switzerland to jointly arrange the closely watched transaction.
The loan represents the bulk of the $1.3 billion debt portion of the deal, which has a total cost of $2.2 billion, the sources said.
Investors are keeping an eye on the financial fortunes of Petrozuata as a barometer for the success of at least five other proposed Orinoco upgrading deals with top U.S. and European companies.
The four banks, which beat out about 19 other institutions that were invited to bid, offered the project partners 14 years in which to pay back the loan.
The group also offered to forego political risk insurance, the sources said.
The winning bid is considered "very aggressive from a banking perspective," a source at a separate financial institution said.
The project partners are now awaiting the imminent release of credit ratings for a bond offering to cover at least part of the remaining debt portion of the project.
Sources say Petrozuata is very likely to secure an investment grade rating, equivalent to Triple-B or better, from at least one of the top rating agencies.
Venezuela has a sovereign credit rating of Single-B from Standard & Poor's and Ba2 from Moody's, both below investment grade.
Petrozuata, a 50-50 joint venture, would produce, upgrade and export Venezuelan extra-heavy crude oil from the country's vast Orinoco Tar Belt.
The partners plan to pump about 120,000 barrels per day (bpd) of extra-heavy crude and upgrade it into 104,000 bpd of 21 API gravity "synthetic" crude for export.
The belt, known in Spanish as the Faja, contains an estimated 270 billion barrels of recoverable extra-heavy crude reserves.
